titlestmt.subtitle: A Finding Aid to the Collection in the Library of Congress
titlestmt.author:
Prepared by Richard Bickel, David Mathisen, William Parham, and Kate Stewart with the assistance of Susie Moody and others
Revised and expanded by T. Micheal Womack

controlnote.p: Converted to EAD3 : Encoded Archival Description (EAD), Version 3 : Release: 1.1.1 : Release Date: 2019-12-16. Validating against latest version of schema.

maintenanceevent.eventdescription: Converted from EAD 2002 to EAD 3 (Release 1.1.1) by ead3_converter_mfer.xsl : Michael Ferrando, Library of Congress.
Finding aid encoded by Library of Congress Manuscript Division

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: United States senator from Ohio, Republican Party leader, and lawyer. Correspondence, family and personal papers, political and legislative files, subject files, business and financial papers, speeches and writings, and other papers relating primarily to Taft's career in the Senate and to his role as a national leader in the Republican Party.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The papers of Robert A. Taft, United States senator from Ohio, Republican Party leader, and lawyer, were given to the Library of Congress from 1953 to 1983 by the Taft family. Additional material was received by gift and transfer, 1954-1987.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The Robert A. Taft Papers were processed in 1959-1960. Additions were made in 1980, 1984, and 1998. The finding aid was revised in 2005 and 2011.

separatedmaterial.head: Transfers
separatedmaterial.p: Items have been transferred from the Manuscript Division to other custodial divisions of the Library. Sound recordings and newsreel film have been transferred to the Motion Picture, Broadcasting and Recorded Sound Division. Photographs have been transferred to the Prints and Photographs Division. All transfers are identified in these divisions as part of the Robert A. Taft Papers.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Copyright in the unpublished writings of Robert A. Taft in these papers and in other collections of papers in the custody of the Library of Congress has been dedicated to the public.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The papers of Robert A. Taft are open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Manuscript Reading Room prior to visiting. Many collections are stored off-site and advance notice is needed to retrieve these items for research use.

accessrestrict.head: Security Classified Documents
accessrestrict.p: Government regulations control the use of security classified items in this collection. Manuscript Division staff can furnish information concerning access to and use of classified material.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Container number, Robert A. Taft Papers, Manuscript Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

chronitem.event: B.A. summa cum laude, Yale University, New Haven, Conn.

chronitemset.event: LL.B. summa cum laude, Harvard University, Cambridge, Mass.

Counsel, American Relief Administration, Paris, France
Republican member of Ohio House of Representatives; elected speaker in 1926
Ohio's "favorite son" for Republican presidential nomination

Chairman, Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee, Eightieth Congress
Published A Foreign Policy for Americans . Garden City, N.Y.: Doubleday

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p:
The papers of Robert Alphonso Taft (1889-1953) span the years 1885-1980, with the bulk of the items concentrated in the period 1938-1953. The papers have been organized in the following series:
Family Papers ,
Personal File ,
General Correspondence ,
Letters Sent ,
Political File ,
Legislative Papers ,
Subject File ,
Special Files ,
Speeches and Writings File ,
Business Papers ,
Miscellany ,
Addition ,
Oversize , and
Top Secret .

Family Papers consist of correspondence and other material documenting the lives of four generations of Tafts. Major correspondents include Robert A. Taft's parents, Helen Herron Taft and William Howard Taft, his sister, Helen Taft Manning, his wife, Martha Wheaton Bowers Taft, and his son, Robert Taft (1917-1993). There is a sizable amount of biographical material on William H. Taft, twenty-seventh president of the United States, including printed matter and correspondence with numerous individuals, among them Henry Pringle, author of The Life and Work of William Howard Taft. The series also contains letters of condolence on the death of both parents.

The
Personal File reflects Taft's early law career and civic engagements in Cincinnati, Ohio; his service during World War I, which included a close association with Herbert Hoover in Washington, D.C., and Paris; and his postwar occupational and political activities in Ohio until 1927.

The
General Correspondence series contains letters and other material related to Taft's numerous business enterprises and associates, his colleagues in the United States Senate, and other friends and acquaintances. This series, as a separate filing unit, was terminated in 1945; thereafter correspondence was filed as political, legislative, or general, with political and legislative correspondence filed chronologically and general correspondence filed alphabetically by subject.

The
Letters Sent series consists of Taft's replies to professional correspondence received. The series serves as a locator for incoming correspondence filed under
Political File ,
Legislative Papers , or
Subject File . Typed in the top margin of each page are cross references to the original item, subject matter, and often Taft's reason for responding.

The most significant series within the collection are
Political File ,
Legislative Papers , and
Subject File . They reflect the development of Taft's political career at both the state and national levels as well as his rise to leadership within the Republican party. The bulk of the
Political File concerns Taft's campaigns for the United States Senate (1938-1950) and for the Republican presidential nomination (1940-1952), with over one-third of the series relating to his bid in 1952. Also notable are files concerning his years in the Ohio state legislature, organized labor's opposition to his Senate campaign of 1950, and its consequent investigation by Congress.

The
Legislative Papers relate to matters of policy and legislation either proposed or enacted into law. They include correspondence, petitions, suggestions, and inquiries concerning programs and positions taken by Taft and the Republican party on local, state, and national issues not found in the more general
Subject File . There are also published committee hearings and reports, files relating to individuals, and letters containing praise, criticism, or suggestions from political leaders and the public. Subjects of note include economics, labor, defense, foreign policy, finance and taxation, and veterans.

The
Subject File represents a broad spectrum of topics concerning public affairs. The series was organized in Taft's senatorial office in 1946 and was used until his death in 1953. The papers, filed chronologically and thereunder alphabetically by subject, illustrate Taft's belief that a politician should not only work for the good of his constituents and the nation as a whole, but also provide moral leadership. On the whole, Taft was a staunch believer in party unity, but at times he was also capable of taking very independent positions on political issues. This paradoxical nature is reflected on the one hand by his intense opposition to certain policies of presidents Roosevelt, Truman, and Eisenhower and on the other hand by his wholehearted support for different policies by the same presidents.

The
Special File consists of material on political figures. These include Thomas E. Dewey, Dwight D. Eisenhower, Herbert Hoover, Harold E. Stassen, Adlai E. Stevenson (1900-1965), and Harry S. Truman.

The
Speeches and Writings File represents a comprehensive collection of Taft's addresses, public statements, radio broadcasts, news releases, and published articles. They are arranged chronologically and thereunder alphabetically by type of material.

The
Business Papers document Taft's financial investments, properties in Ohio and in Washington, D.C., philanthropic support for artistic and cultural institutions, personal finances, as well as estate papers of several Taft family members.

The
Miscellany series contains appointment books, clippings, galley proofs and correspondence relating to Taft's 1951 publication
A Foreign Policy for Americans, honorary degrees and citations for service, letters of condolence, material concerning both the Taft family summer home and a fish and game club in Canada, and also material documenting Taft's long relationship with his alma mater Yale University.

The
Addition
consists of family papers, general correspondence, political material, speeches and writings, business papers, and miscellaneous material. Of note are Martha Bowers Taft's political correspondence and speeches, illustrating her skill as campaigner and speaker in her own right as well as her more traditional role as politician's wife. There are letters from William H. Taft while chief justice of the Supreme Court to his son Robert Alphonso in which he discusses contemporary judicial topics. Also of interest is the file detailing the establishment of a memorial to the twenty-seventh president in Arlington National Cemetery. Robert A. Taft's life is chronicled by the files containing his speeches, records concerning the settling of his personal estate, clippings and other biographical material, as well as numerous letter of condolence written to both his wife and son Robert, Jr. The public's appreciation of Taft's life and achievements are evident in files documenting memorials to Taft in Cincinnati and Washington, D.C.

Oversize
material consists of an architectural sketch, memorial resolutions in honor of Robert A. Taft, photostatic copies, and scrapbooks.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Papers
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in fourteen series:

scopecontent.p: Letters sent and received by family members. Includes posthumous correspondence and biographical and photographic material relating to William H. Taft.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by name of individual and chronologically thereunder.

did.unittitle:
Taft, Helen (sister)
See also Container 17, Manning, Frederick J. and Helen Taft
Correspondence with Robert A. Taft, 1905-1943, undated

Taft, Martha Bowers (wife)
See also Containers 16-17, Bowers Family, general
Pringle, Henry, re Life and Work of William Howard Taft, 1930-1951
Manning, Frederick J. and Helen Taft (brother-in-law and sister), 1933-1953, undated

scopecontent.p: Correspondence and records concerning Taft's law practice and civic activities in Cincinnati, Ohio, the selective service, United States Food Administration in Washington, D.C., and American Relief Administration in Paris, France.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by subject and chronologically thereunder.

did.unittitle: Mayor's budget, tax rates and statistics, 1921
Ohio ex rel. Keller v. Tax Commission, 1923
Ohio taxation, McCrehen v. Brown, O.S.C. No. 18199, 1923

scopecontent.p: Letters sent and received and miscellaneous material related to Taft's business enterprises, Senate colleagues, and other friends. Also included is a container of general correspondence related to Martha Bowers Taft.

arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically and alphabetically thereunder according to name of person, organization, geographic address, or subject.

scopecontent.p: Copies of replies to professional correspondence.

arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically and alphabetically thereunder by name of person or organization.

scopecontent.p: Letters received and sent, Republican party activities, statements, news releases, clippings, and texts of radio broadcasts, campaign literature, petitions, primary and general election materials, states subject files, minorities activities, patronage matters, and voter lists.

arrangement.p: Filed chronologically by campaign and alphabetically thereunder by type of material or name of person, organization, or subject.
